an9.72:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five shackles of the heart.

an9.72:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāmesu avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
an9.72:1.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

an9.72:1.4.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāmesu avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an9.72:1.4.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an9.72:1.5.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, ayaṃ paṭhamo cetasovinibandho.
an9.72:1.5.eng: This is the first shackle of the heart.

an9.72:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye avītarāgo hoti …pe…
an9.72:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body …

an9.72:2.2.eng: They’re not free of greed for form …

an9.72:2.3.pli: yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati …
an9.72:2.3.eng: They eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …

an9.72:2.4.pli: aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti.
an9.72:2.4.eng: They lead the spiritual life wishing to be reborn in one of the orders of gods: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’

an9.72:2.5.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an9.72:2.5.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an9.72:2.6.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, ayaṃ pañcamo cetasovinibandho.
an9.72:2.6.eng: This is the fifth shackle of the heart.

an9.72:2.7.eng: These are the five shackles of the heart.

an9.72:3.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ cetasovinibandhānaṃ pahānāya cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā.
an9.72:3.1.eng: To give up these five shackles of the heart you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

an9.72:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
an9.72:3.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an9.72:3.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

an9.72:3.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …

an9.72:3.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
an9.72:3.6.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an9.72:3.7.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ cetasovinibandhānaṃ pahānāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.72:3.7.eng: To give up these five shackles of the heart you should develop these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

an9.73:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five weaknesses when you’re training.

an9.73:1.3.eng: Killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an9.73:1.4.eng: These are the five weaknesses when you’re training.

an9.73:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ sikkhādubbalyānaṃ pahānāya cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā.
an9.73:2.1.eng: To give up these five weaknesses in your training you should develop the four right efforts.

an9.73:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
an9.73:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

an9.73:2.4.pli: uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
an9.73:2.4.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

an9.73:2.5.pli: anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
an9.73:2.5.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

an9.73:2.6.pli: uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
an9.73:2.6.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

an9.73:2.7.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ sikkhādubbalyānaṃ pahānāya ime cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.73:2.7.eng: To give up these five weaknesses in your training you should develop these four right efforts.”

an9.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
an9.8:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

an9.8:1.2.pli: Atha kho sajjho paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an9.8:1.2.eng: Then the wanderer Sajjha went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an9.8:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sajjho paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an9.8:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an9.8:2.1.pli: “Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ bhagavā idheva rājagahe viharāmi giribbaje.
an9.8:2.1.eng: “Sir, this one time the Buddha was staying right here in Rājagaha, the Mountainfold.

an9.8:2.2.pli: Tatra me, bhante, bhagavato sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
an9.8:2.2.eng: There I heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

an9.8:2.3.pli: ‘yo so, sajjha, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so pañca ṭhānāni ajjhācarituṃ—
an9.8:2.3.eng: ‘A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in five respects.

an9.8:2.4.pli: abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropetuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādātuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevituṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṃ kāme paribhuñjituṃ seyyathāpi pubbe agāriyabhūto’ti.
an9.8:2.4.eng: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they did as a layperson.’

an9.8:2.5.pli: Kacci metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sussutaṃ suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritan”ti?
an9.8:2.5.eng: I trust I properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered that from the Buddha?”

an9.8:3.1.pli: “Taggha te etaṃ, sajjha, sussutaṃ suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ.
an9.8:3.1.eng: “Indeed, Sajjha, you properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered that.

an9.8:3.2.pli: Pubbe cāhaṃ, sajjha, etarahi ca evaṃ vadāmi:
an9.8:3.2.eng: In the past, as today, I say this:

an9.8:3.3.pli: ‘yo so bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so nava ṭhānāni ajjhācarituṃ—
an9.8:3.3.eng: ‘A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in nine respects.

an9.8:3.4.pli: abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropetuṃ …pe… abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṃ kāme paribhuñjituṃ seyyathāpi pubbe agāriyabhūto, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu buddhaṃ paccakkhātuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu dhammaṃ paccakkhātuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu saṅghaṃ paccakkhātuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sikkhaṃ paccakkhātuṃ’.
an9.8:3.4.eng: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately kill a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they used to as a layperson. And they can’t abandon the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, or the training.’

an9.8:3.5.pli: Pubbe cāhaṃ, sajjha, etarahi ca evaṃ vadāmi:
an9.8:3.5.eng: In the past, as today, I say this:

an9.8:3.6.pli: ‘yo so bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so imāni nava ṭhānāni ajjhācaritun’”ti.
an9.8:3.6.eng: ‘A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in these nine respects.’”

an9.83:0.3.eng: Weaknesses in Training and the Bases of Psychic Power

an9.83:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five weaknesses when you’re training.

an9.83:1.3.eng: Killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an9.83:1.4.eng: These are the five weaknesses when you’re training.

an9.83:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ sikkhādubbalyānaṃ pahānāya cattāro iddhipādā bhāvetabbā.
an9.83:2.1.eng: To give up these five weaknesses in your training you should develop the four bases of psychic power.

an9.83:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti,
an9.83:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

an9.83:2.4.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort.

an9.83:2.5.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.

an9.83:2.6.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.

an9.83:2.7.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ sikkhādubbalyānaṃ pahānāya ime cattāro iddhipādā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.83:2.7.eng: To give up these five weaknesses in your training you should develop these four bases of psychic power.”

an9.9:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these nine individuals are found in the world.

an9.9:1.3.pli: Arahā, arahattāya paṭipanno, anāgāmī, anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno, sakadāgāmī, sakadāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno, sotāpanno, sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno, puthujjano—
an9.9:1.3.eng: The perfected one and the one practicing for perfection. The non-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of non-return. The once-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of once-return. The stream-enterer and the one practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry. And the ordinary person.

an9.9:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, nava puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an9.9:1.4.eng: These are the nine individuals found in the world.”

an9.93:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, nine things should be developed.

an9.93:1.3.pli: Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā—
an9.93:1.3.eng: The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, and fading away.

an9.93:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime nava dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.93:1.4.eng: For insight into greed, these nine things should be developed.”

an9.94:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, nine things should be developed.

an9.94:1.3.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ, dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ, catutthaṃ jhānaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ, viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ, ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ, saññāvedayitanirodho—
an9.94:1.3.eng: The first absorption, the second absorption, the third absorption, the fourth absorption, the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness, the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the cessation of perception and feeling.

an9.94:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime nava dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.94:1.4.eng: For insight into greed, these nine things should be developed.”
